key_work.title: Bwana Devil
key_work.brief_description: Filmmakers felt threatened by the arrival of TV in 1948 and sought ways to keep audiences coming to cinemas. One way was 3D movies, and Bwana Devil was the first 3D colour feature film.

end.title: Coat hangers
end.brief_description: “No! Wire! Hangers … ever!” The now famous line from 1981 kitsch classic Mommie Dearest depicted coat hangers as the bane of Joan Crawford’s existence (among other things). And while that might be true in the context of this docudrama, they’ve also been a consistent presence on film sets since the dawn of the moving image. Practical and ingenious, coat hangers come in all shapes and sizes. This simple domestic object has been handmade or manufactured in wood, metal, plastic or wire. (The wire ones could also be bent into a map-of-Australia car aerial!) Coat hangers are an essential tool in the costume department.

links.description: Feud details the rivalry between Joan Crawford and Bette Davis. In Mommie Dearest, Crawford is played by Faye Dunaway, and in the film’s most memorable scene, furiously declares “No! Wire! Hangers!… ever!”

end.title: Raw
end.creator_credit: Jean des Forêts, Julie Gayet, Nadia Turincev, ARTE, CNC, Focus Features and RTBF

video_links.name: RAW I Official Red Band Trailer [HD] l In theatres March 10, 2017

end.brief_description: In Justine’s family everyone is a vet and a vegetarian. At 16, she’s a gifted teen ready to take on her first year in vet school, where her older sister studies. When Justine is forced to eat raw meat during a hazing ritual, unexpected consequences emerge.

links.description: The legacy of William Castle lived on during the theatrical release of Julia Ducournau’s Raw (2016). Instead of axes, ushers at a Los Angeles theatre handed out vomit bags prior to the screening.

start.title: Scent of Mystery
start.creator_credit: Michael Todd Jr. and Michael Todd Company
start.brief_description: Scent of Mystery is a 1960 mystery film, the first to use the Smell-O-Vision system to release odors at points in the film’s plot. It was the first film in which aromas were integral to the story, providing important details to the audience.

end.title: Polyester
end.creator_credit: John Waters, Van Smith and New Line Cinema
end.headline_credit: United States and United States of America, 1981
end.brief_description: A comedy melodrama of the tragic life of Francine Fishpaw (Divine), an obese housewife whose mere existence burdens her so-called loved ones. Mistreated by her husband Elmer, who runs the local porn theatre and money-hungry mother, La Rue, she turns to the bottle.

links.description: Heavily inspired by Scent of Mystery, John Waters’ Polyester (1981) was presented in “Odorama”. Audiences were given scratch n’ sniff cards revealing plot-related smells at key moments.

end.title: Hagsploitation
end.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
end.brief_description: Whatever Happened to Baby Jane? was a surprise hit that spawned ‘hagsploitation’, a genre of campy thrillers and horror movies that resurrected stars of yesteryear. The films provided roles, but they were grotesque caricatures of aging that persist in films today.
